channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HADOOP-14170] FileSystemContractBaseTest is not cleaning up test directory clearly
item.description:
In FileSystemContractBaseTest::tearDown() method, it cleans up the path("/test") directory, which will be qualified as /test (against root instead of working directory because it's absolute):

  @Override
  protected void tearDown() throws Exception {
    try {
      if (fs != null) {
        fs.delete(path("/test"), true);
      }
    } catch (IOException e) {
      LOG.error("Error deleting /test: " + e, e);
    }
  }

But in the test, it uses path("test") sometimes, which will be made qualified against the working directory (e.g. /user/bob/test).

This makes some tests fail intermittently, e.g. ITestS3AFileSystemContract. Also see the discussion in HADOOP-13934.
item.summary: FileSystemContractBaseTest is not cleaning up test directory clearly

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
One simple solution is to clean up this directory as well in tearDown() method. This is not enough because subclass may need to use different test root (e.g. S3A using /forkid for parallel tests), but the existing tests are still using /test instead.

Another approach is to use method-specific sub-directory for each test case in which way they don't interfere with each other. But we still need to clean up both /test and /user/bob/test after the whole test. Or we can address that later after this patch.

I think a feasible solution is to always use path("test") for normal tests except those tests against root (e.g. testRootDirAlwaysExists()) in which case we have to use path("/test"). This should be clear in each test case - test root or not. I'll upload a patch for this solution.

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.

good catch.

One reason I've been switching to different paths in different tests, including different test cases, is to avoid consistency problems against object stores: in an eventually consistent FS, tests may think they've cleaned up, but really they haven't.

!. We could just have path(String) add a standard prefix like "test/", then have the cleanup do the delete of the path above that test dir?

The v2 patch is to:

  1. Use per-test directory (different paths in different tests)
  2. Add a standard prefix FileSystemContractBaseTest from working directory in path(pathString) so that we can cleanup the prefix directory safely without deleting user data accidently. The default prefix will be /user/$USER/FileSystemContractBaseTest, and subclass can override this (e.g. S3A has /user/$USER/s3afilesystemcontract/FileSystemContractBaseTest or {{ /user/$USER/$FORKID/FileSystemContractBaseTest).

LGTM, +1

Reviewing this I realised that I'd got confused about tests. FileSystemContractBaseTest is the old JUnit 3.x test suite, not the newer AbstractFSContractTestBase tests. That's fairly old piece of code I've always left alone fearing that external projects had subclassed it and so we couldn't break it.

your patch is the first bit of long-needed maintenance it's had for a while.

This makes me thing: it's time to move this to JUnit 4, annotate all tests with @test, and make the test cases skip if they don't have the test FS defined. JUnit 3 doesn't support Assume, so when I do test runs without the s3n or s3 fs specced, I get lots of errors I just ignore.

What do you think? Move to Junit 4, and, in our own code, find everywhere we've subclassed a method to make the test a no-op, and insert an Assume.assumeTrue(false) in there so they skip properly?

SUCCESS: Integrated in Jenkins build Hadoop-trunk-Commit #11397 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/Hadoop-trunk-Commit/11397/)

  • (edit) hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/test/java/org/apache/hadoop/fs/TestRawLocalFileSystemContract.java
Committed to trunk branch. Uploading a branch-2 patch. Thanks Steve for review, I've filed HADOOP-14180 to address the upgrading JUnit 3 -> 4 problem.
